captions.text: Olive oil is 100% fat;
there's nothing else in it.
Pancake mix, on the other hand,
is only about 11% fat.
And, yet, olive oil is good for you,
and pancake mix is not.
Why is that?
As it turns out,
the amount of fat we eat
doesn't impact our weight
or our cholesterol
or our risk of heart disease
nearly as much as what kind of fat we eat.
But let's back up:
What is fat?
If we were to zoom in on a salmon,
which is a fatty fish,
past the organs,
past the tissues,
into the cells,
we would see that the stuff we call fat
is actually made up of molecules called triglycerides,
and they are not all alike.
Here's one example.
Those three carbons on the left, that's glycerol.
Now, you can think of that as the backbone
that holds the rest of the molecule together.
The three long chains on the right
are called fatty acids,
and it's subtle differences in the structures of these chains
that determine whether a fat is,
let's say,  solid or liquid;
whether or not it goes rancid quickly;
and, most importantly, how good or how bad it is for you.
Let's take a look at some of these differences.
One is length.
Fatty acids can be short or long.
Another, more important difference
is the type of bond between the carbon atoms.
Some fatty acids have only single bonds.
Others have both single and double bonds.
Fatty acids with only single bonds
are called saturated,
and those with one or more double bonds
are called unsaturated.
Now, most unsaturated fats are good for you,
while saturated fats are bad for you in excess.
For saturated fats, the story pretty much ends there
but not for unsaturated fats.
The double bonds in these molecules
have a kind of weird property;
they're rigid.
So, that means there are two ways
to arrange every double bond.
The first is like this,
where both hydrogens are on same side
and both carbons are on the same side.
The second way is like this.
Now the hydrogens and carbons
are on opposite sides of the double bond.
Now, even though both of these molecules
are made up of exactly the same building blocks,
they are two completely different substances,
and they behave completely differently inside of us.
The configuration on the left is called CIS,
which you've probably never heard of.
The one of the right is called TRANS,
and you probably have heard of trans fats before.
They don't go rancid,
they're more stable during deep frying,
and they can change the texture of foods
in ways that other fats just can't.
They're also terrible for your health,
by far worse than saturated fat,
even though technically they're a type
of unsaturated fat.
Now, I know that seems crazy,
but your body doesn't care
what a molecule looks like on paper.
All that matters is the 3-D shape
where the molecule fits,
where it doesn't,
and what pathways it interferes with.
So, how do you know if a food
has trans fat in it?
Well, the only sure way to know
is if you see the words,
"partially hydrogenated" in the ingredients list.
Don't let nutrition labels or advertising fool you.
The FDA allows manufacturers to claim
that their products contain
"0" grams of trans fat
even if they actually have up to half a gram per serving.
But there are no hard and fast rules
about how small a serving can be,
and, that means, you'll have to rely on seeing those key words,
partially hydrogenated,
because that's how trans fats are made,
by partially hydrogenating unsaturated fats.
So, let's go back to our olive oil and pancake mix from before.
Olive oil is 100% fat.
Pancake mix is only 11% fat.
But olive oil is mostly unsaturated fat,
and it has no trans fat at all.
On the other hand, more than half the fat
in pancake mix is either saturated or trans fat.
And, so, even though olive oil has 10 times
as much fat as pancake mix,
it's healthy for you,
whereas pancake mix is not.
Now, I'm not trying to pick on pancake mix.
There are lots of foods
with this type of fat profile.
The point is this:
It's not how much fat you eat,
it's what kind of fat.
And what makes a particular fat healthy or unhealthy
is its shape.

comments.author: J. Boyle

comments.text:
+J. Boyle More Hydrogen IS saturated; When it has only single bonds because 
of all the Carbon in the fat has bonded to as much Hydrogen as possible so 
there are no double bonds, this makes it *saturated* with Hydrogen. Less 
Hydrogen, therefore more double bonds, makes the molecule *unsaturated*. So 
you were right the first time with your water analogy. :D
comments.author: MrKinkyPixel

comments.text:

thing that always wants my brain to think the opposite is when I think 
saturated, I think wet, which makes me think water, and I think hydrogen, 
whereas more hydrogen is actually unsaturated.
comments.author: J. Boyle

comments.text:
Basically (natural) oils like olive oils are liquid. The reason why they 
are liquid is because they are unsaturated (they have fewer hydrogens) and 
because of that the molecules do not fit together that well, which lowers 
the fat's melting point. Meanwhile animal fats are often solid because they 
are saturated. However, food manufacturers often want to make plant oils 
more solid. So they need to add hydrogens to the carbons in the double 
bonds. (double bonds break and carbons form new bonds with hydrogens) Now 
the fat molecule has been partially hydrogenated. Now to the important 
part. Normally all of the double bonds in natural fats are 
cis-configuration. However, during this partial hydrogenation of fats, some 
of the cis- bonds switch to the trans configuration which is unnatural and 
genrally not that good for you.

I think the reason they only partially hydrogenate the fats is because they 
do not want to make the fat too solid.

I am not saying everything I said is right. but that is what I have 
gathered from school. Hope it helps.

comments.author: Eric Gerds

comments.text:
(good video)
Naturally occurring unsaturated fats are always cis.    The trans fat looks 
like a perfect competitive inhibitor.  That is, it looks like a poison.    
The trans configuration is the less constrained so that if the molecule is 
upset, (heating, or even during the hydrogenation ) the molecule might flip 
to the trans as this is the energetically more stable. 
The  unsaturated fatty acid molecules are more energetic.  That is, they 
are somewhat thermodynamically unstable.  Manufacturers of processed food 
like to use partially hydrogenated fat because it is more stable and more 
predictable in its behavior.﻿

comments.text:
robertomasymas Has posted misinformation based on outdated thinking that 
was purely intuitive (lacking evidence).  Fat is quite healthy and 
necessary in the diet.  Normal, correct use of oil will not result in the 
creation of trans fats.  Saturated fat is even important for the health of 
bones and skin, as well as other body systems.  There really isn't a 
"healthy" amount of fat, as the type of and ratio of fats is far more 
important.  This is why the Inuit diet is "healthy."  The blubber they are 
eating contains almost a 1:2 ratio of omega-3 to omega-6 fatty acids.  Many 
of our "healthy" monounsaturated fats generally have ratios from 1:4 to 1:20
.

 The "fat free" craze has been shown to be harmful and dangerous.﻿

comments.author: Dolev W

comments.text:
Not that I don't appreciate the video! But ... 
A problem in this presentation is that olive oil is only "healthy" (meaning 
not a high risk factor for heart disease) when it is not heated to excess. 
Heating olive oil provides an opportunity to oxidize and change it from CIS 
to TRANS fats .. this can start to happen in a big way when the temperature 
gets near the smoke point of the oil, but because of turbulence and oil 
sticking in a thin layer at certain places, and unevenness of heat, it 
happens even at lower temperatures in lesser amounts. In the USA we also 
get _many times_ the amount of fatty acids we need in our diet. Basically, 
oil is never healthy for you — especially not when you cook with it — but 
the amount that is converted into trans fats will be low if you stay far 
away from the smoke point of the oil, and don't cook with it for very long.﻿
comments.author: robertomasymas

comments.text:
+Tyler Hamilton "I have to agree with takaditakadang when they say that 
your statement that all oil is never healthy for you is misleading and not 
really accurate at all. "
I think this is the thing that most people take issue with. They are 
thinking "hey, there are essential fatty acids!" and that is true. But you 
need almost no fats .. literally some hundreds of milligrams per day in 
total. People consume tens of grams per day. When the diet is already 
overrun with fats, adding more is just bad for you. You could say "too much 
of a good thing", but that is really painting too rosy a picture.

We don't disagree about cholesterol, except that fats *are converted* into 
cholesterol in the body — it is this process that builds the cell walls, 
aids in cellular division, and it is the reason why there *are* essential 
fatty acids at all. And there is a direct correlation, one of the strongest 
and most fleshed out in medicine, between cholesterol in the blood and CVD.
comments.author: robertomasymas

to do with the fat found in vegetable based cooking oil. I have to agree

comments.text:
+Ben Miller You have an outdated, prejudiced way of thinking that would 
have stood out even during the civil rights movement. Okay, maybe that is 
an exaggeration — but I don't feel bad. :)
Not only are the things I say accurate to state-of-the-art understanding 
going back decades ago, but they *remain as the foundations* of modern 
health to this day.
Please don't respond to me, I'm going to just ignore you. I was completely 
turned off by your approach and barely wanted to respond at all. I have 
house plants with more charm than you have.
comments.author: robertomasymas

comments.text:
+Roberto Tomás You have an outdated simplistic view of nutrition based on 
thinking from over two decades ago.

In the meantime, healthy diets contain a lot of fat.  It's a very necessary 
nutrient.  You have weak knowledge about nutrition and biology, so you 
probably should keep it to yourself, lest you reveal your ignorance to 
those around you.  Here, let's take a look:

"Just because Inuits. . ."  LMFAO!  What a completely unsubstantiated 
statement!  You have, literally, zero evidence to support this except that 
you'd like it to be the case.  If you don't understand how to think 
scientifically, shut up.

"Within this culture here in the USA, there is a direct correlation between 
a person's cholesterol levels. . . cholesterol in the blood increases with 
fats in diet"  This is grossly oversimplified.  Diet has a very small 
effect on cholesterol levels.  Of things you can control, exercise is far 
more effective.  Of course, if you knew anything at all about human biology 
(you don't), you'd know that the biggest factor is genetics.  And you've 
also failed to point out what kinds of fats.  When most people are 
consuming mostly bad fats, just saying "fats in diet (sic)" is horribly 
inadequate, and if you understood nutrition, you'd know that.

No, cooking with monounsaturated fats does not create trans fats, at least 
not when used properly.  You could, I suppose, reuse the fat over and over 
and over for a very long time, and after many, many hours of use, you'd 
have a small amount of trans fat, but that'd be stupid, just from a 
culinary standpoint, because the oil was denatured and contaminated during 
the first use and should not have been used again.  So yeah, I suppose if 
you're a culinary dunce, then you might create some trans fats.  Pfft.

Haha, and your 30x, 10x, "no culture anywhere on earth where people eat 
only a healthy amount of fat — everyone eats too much" nonsense is total 
fucking crap!  Holy shit, do you get your jollies from making shit up? 
 LMAO.  Many Americans don't get enough fat because of the residual from 
the incredibly outdated "fat free" craze.  What's more, many people 
honestly really need to up their saturated fat intake, because their skin 
and bones are crap.  Of course, since you're incredibly ignorant about 
nutrition, you're probably thinking "What does saturated fat have to do 
with skin and bones?"  And that's just another example of why your thinking 
is incredibly outdated.

Anyway, my point is, get with the new millennium.  Some of what you said 
may have had support back in the 80s, maybe a bit in the 90s, but that sort 
of thinking has no place anymore in modern nutrition, as science (like, 
experimentation) has overwhelmingly shown the intuition behind it to be 
horribly flawed, like the sort of intuition you're using.
comments.author: Ben Miller

comments.text:
+IMPERIUS well I said a lot, each likely I learned from different sources. 
I use nutritionfacts.org a lot (so does Keiser Permanente now) .. and they

comments.author: Roberto Tomás

comments.text:
+IMPERIUS I disagree: There's nothing misleading about it. The average 
american eats more than 30 *times* the amount of fat they need. — that's 
not the extreme, that is the *average*. The global average is still well 
over 10 times. There is no culture anywhere on earth where people eat only 
a healthy amount of fat — everyone eats too much. So the *lifestyle* 
argument is completely out the window. Same with genes, since that would 
have to go hand in hand with lifestyle.
comments.author: Roberto Tomás

comments.text:
+takaditakadang well, we disagree then. Within this culture here in the 
USA, there is a direct correlation between a person's cholesterol levels 
and their life expectancy. Regardless of culture, cholesterol *in the blood* 
increases with fats in diet: leading to the unambiguous claim that eating 
more fat shortens your life expectancy. Switching gears to cultural 
comparisons, the cultures that live the longest all tend (comparatively) 
towards vegetarianism and low fat diets. Just because Inuits can live well 
into their 60s while eating seal blubber half the year doesn't mean that 
they wouldnt live well into their 90s if they cut that shit out.
comments.author: Roberto Tomás

comments.text:
Monounsaturated fats and even more so polyunsaturated fats oxidize much 
more readily than saturated fats and therefore are not suited to high 
temperature cooking. When they remain in their unoxidized forms, they are 
some of the healthiest things to consume. 

Your blanket statement that oils are *never* healthy for you is bullshit. 
Some cultures consume almost 50 percent of their calories in fat, saturated 
fat particularly (coconut oil) and their rate of diabetes, cancer, and 
heart disease is almost nonexistent.

comments.text:
Thanks! - Learning to think for myself in today's world of distorted 
"infu-namis" is really hard. 
  At the end of the day, all this information has to come down to some kind 
of grounded reality, and right now, I just want to really understand enough 
to enjoy eating while optimizing youth, longevity and fun - all of which 
really make a difference in helping me in life and work. 
   Belated Happy New Year
comments.author: Savage Insight

comments.text:
+MrJeb123 Thanks - I wonder much the same. The issue isn't chemistry, but 
industry standard. Somehow strict words like "hydrogenated" become a 
subjected quality. 
  In either case, I'll remember to add calcium to any saturated foods eat.
comments.author: Savage Insight

comments.text:
I think it would become saturated fat then, because fully or partially 
hydrogenated refers to how many hydrogen atoms are connected to the carbons 
by bonds. I haven't taken too much organic chemistry but in order to have 
everything Fully hydrogenated you need to have all single bonds, which it 
the saturated fats.
comments.author: MrJeb123

comments.author: adrian gil

comments.text:
+james pogrebetsky is guilty of equivocation and over simplification. "Fat" 
used in "unsaturated fat" means "triglycerides", which can be good in 
certain amounts. "Fat" used in "a fat person" refers to someone overweight 
and may face health problems as a result. The two forms of "Fat" don't even 
share a part of speech, so comparing "Unsaturated fat" to "fat person" is 
ludicrous.
comments.author: brotherbandit

comments.text:
+Dragon 9  No, that is saying that unsaturated fat is good, and therefor if 
you call a fat person that, you are calling them something good.
